dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A million suns shine in the dark. A STARSHIP cuts through the night: a gleaming white cruis Galleries of windows. Flying decks and observation domes. On the hull: EXCELSIOR - A HomeStead Company Starship. The ship flashes through a nebula. Space-dust sparkles as whips over the hull, betraying the ship's dizzying speed. The nebula boils in the ship's wake. The Excelsior rocket on, spotless and beautiful as a daydream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide plaza. Its lofty atrium cuts through seven decks, creating tiers of promenades framing a vast skylight. The promenades are empty. Chairs unoccupied. Beetle-like robots vacuum the carpets and wax the floors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Super-modern and gleaming. Hundreds of tables, all empty.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Lounge furniture and star-filled windows. Completely deserted. A robot on spindly legs washes the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Endless corridors lined with vertical glass tubes. Inside each tube stands a PASSENGER. Eyes closed in sleep. If they're breathing you can't tell by looking. They sleep on their feet, leaning against padded supports Straps secure them in place; sensors adhere to their skin They wear shorts and tank tops with HomeStead Company log We survey their faces. No children, no senior citizens. M and women of every ethnicity in the prime of their lives. We settle on one man. JIM PRESTON, 38. Sound asleep. A sm display on his pod reads:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rate 2 Mechanical Engineer Denver, Colorado

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blood type: A+ Passenger class: silver

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A deep BOOM. Echoes roll down the corridors. Lights wink on in Jim's hibernation pod. Machinery hums t life. Instruments beep and chitter. Medical data fills the pod's screen. Jim's temperature ri His heart begins to beat. He takes a breath. Jim opens his eyes. Groggy, blinking, seeing nothing. The backrest behind him converts into a recliner, lowerin him into a seated position. The sensors on his skin drop off and snake back into the pod's machinery. A video screen descends before Jim's eyes. ONSCREEN - A beautiful stewardess appears, beaming at the camera. She is inhumanly perfect, a computer-generated im

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good Morning, James!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim. What the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Jim. It's normal to feel confused. You've just spent a hundred and twenty years in suspended animation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She makes it sound sexy. Jim scowls and rubs his eyes. ONSCREEN - An animation. Happy people go to sleep in glas tubes in a hospital. The tubes are loaded onto a spaceshi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a passenger on the Starship Excelsior - a Homestead Company Starship. We've nearly completed the 120-year flight from Earth to your new home - the colony world of Homestead II. Congratulations!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN - The Excelsior leaves a skyscraper-covered Eart and soars through space to a lush green Homestead II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Excelsior is on final approach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the next two months, you'll enjoy luxury space travel. Food. Fun. New friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN - The ship's lavish amenities: fine dining, spor facilities, shops, all swarming with happy passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then you'll start your new life on Homestead II. Back to basics. A fresh start. Room to grow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN - Publicity shots of Homestead II. Mountains, forests, beaches. Settlements ringed by farmland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your wake-up capsules and nutrient juice will help you recover from hibernation!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pills rattle into a dish; a glass of pink juice appears. takes his pills and gulps his juice with a grimace. Jim's backrest eases him onto his feet. A drawer pops ope revealing a Homestead Company bathrobe and slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make yourself comfortable in your complimentary robe and slippers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts them on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your shipcard is your key to the starship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't lose it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pod produces Jim's shipcard: a plastic ID card on a lanyard. He hangs it around his neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're ready to go to your cabin. Make yourself at home! Enjoy the rest of your voyage, Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim steps out of his pod into the corridor. All the other pods are closed, the people inside asleep. look of concern crosses Jim's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, your cabin is this way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen flips around to face him. The video stewardess points down the corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take Elevator D to deck seven. Your cabin number is on your shipcard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He shuffles down the corridor in his slippers, rubbing hi face. Having trouble keeping his eyes open. Behind him, his pod closes up. Its screen reads PASSENGER DISCHARGED.  ELEVATOR FOYER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim finds a bank of elevators. As he approaches, the indicators blink on. An elevator opens, spilling light. He steps inside, and muzak begins to play.  DECK SEVEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A corridor lined with doors. A CLEANING ROBOT vacuums. Jim appears. Instantly the corridor lights brighten. The cleaning robot rolls past Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, robot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim follows wall markings to his cabin. Lets himself in.  JIM'S CABIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cozy but small. A bed, a desk, an armchair. No window. A SCREEN lights up. The HomeStead Company theme music pla An ANNOUNCER speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to your cabin, Jim! Your home until we make landfall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim doesn't pay attention. Pokes around, opening drawers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the next two months, you'll prepare for your new life on Homestead II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim peers into the tiny bathroom. There's a little video screen, and the presentation's running there too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passengers are organized into Learning Groups for orientation. You've been assigned to Learning group...thirty-eight! Don't forget!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN: "Learning Group 38." The DOORBELL rings. Jim opens the door eagerly - and deflates. No one there. He looks down. A waist-high CARGO ROBOT peers up at him w goggle eyes. It carries two suitcases and a duffel bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passenger James Preston?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your luggage, Passenger Jim. Swipe your shipcard to confirm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim swipes his shipcard through a slot on top of the robo The robot scoots inside and deposits Jim's bags on the fl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enjoy your luggage!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, Passenger Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The robot zips out the door. Jim looks up and down the corridor. The receding robot is only sign of life. He steps back inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your group's orientation starts in forty-five minutes. Join them in Conference Room Twenty on Deck One. Don't forget!

dialogues.speaker: DECK FOUR
dialogues.text: A mall with tiled floors and ornate storefronts. Jim walks along in his robe and slippers. Storefront sign flicker to life as he passes. A dry fountain gushes water at his approach.

dialogues.speaker: DECK ONE
dialogues.text: Forty chairs around a big table. A large screen on the wa ONSCREEN: A digital INSTRUCTOR, a handsome woman of middl age, waits with a computer's infinite patience. Jim walks in. The door slides closed behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Passengers. Will you all please take a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks around. He's the only one there. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earth is a prosperous planet. The cradle of civilization. A world with a long, proud history. But for many, it's also overpopulated. Over-priced. Overrated. Overrun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind the Instructor, video clips of Earth's urban spraw an endless gleaming metropolis glittering with traffic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (raising his hand) Can I just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No questions until the end, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Where are all the other...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Colonies offer an alternative. A better way of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen fills with shots of Homestead II: aerial foota of mountains, beaches, beautiful garden cities.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And none is more beautiful than Homestead II, the Jewel of the Occupied Worlds.

dialogues.speaker: ONE HOUR LATER
dialogues.text: Jim sits wearily, chin propped on his hand. The Video Instructor chatters on. Inspiring footage of Homestead II

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...thriving job markets in mining, farming and manufacturing. An explosion in the cultural arts. And if you long for the life less civilized, you can apply for a pioneer permit and seek your fortune in the wild. (a pregnant pause) Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where IS everybody?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Instructor pauses. The question seems to confuse her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all on the Starship Excelsior. Five thousand passengers and fifty- eight crew members.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm the only one awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, all the passengers wake up at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then something's wrong with the other hibernation pods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibernation pods are fail-safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So why am I the only one here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I don't understand your question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim finds an INFOMAT - an information kiosk. A banner scr across the screen: ASK ME A QUESTION! Jim taps the screen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello! What's your question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to talk to a person. A real live person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of person? Personal trainer? Travel planner? Therapist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ship Steward handles passenger affairs. You can find him in his office on the Service Deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN: A dotted line on the map shows how to get there

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to help!

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE DECK
dialogues.text: Jim appears around the corner. The lights brighten, the ventilation kicks up a notch. He finds a door marked SHIP STEWARD.

dialogues.speaker: SHIP STEWARD'S OFFICE
dialogues.text: The lights flash on as Jim enters, revealing...an office mothballs. Empty chairs, barren desks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not good.  ELEVATOR LOBBY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another Infomat. Jim arrives at a jog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello! What's your quest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's flying the ship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bridge crew includes the Captain, the Pilot, the Chief Navigator...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain. I want to talk to the Captain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain rarely handles passenger queries directly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emergency, okay? Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain is usually found on the Bridge, on the Command Deck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN: A helpful map shows the way. Jim marches off.  COMMAND DECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim finds the door to the Bridge. He opens it eagerly - o to find a second door behind it - an armored hatch labele FIREWALL and SECURE ACCESS AREA. A porthole of thick glass gives a narrow view of the Brid It's deserted. Instrument lights gleam in the dark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pounding on the hatch) Come on! What the hell is happening?

dialogues.speaker: DECK THREE
dialogues.text: Jim RUNS past restaurants, lounges, shops. All deserted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (panic in his voice) Hello? Hello!

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE DECK
dialogues.text: The highest promenade on the ship: windows on all sides. huge skylight just overhead. It's almost like being outsi The atrium plunges seven stories to the Concourse below.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an echoing shout) Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A SOUND behind him makes him spin. But it's just a window-washer: a robot with long spindly limbs. It moves past Jim, polishing windows. Oblivious. A sign catches Jim's attention: "OBSERVATORY - Your Place the Universe."  OBSERVATORY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim enters the planetarium of the future: theater seats facing a holographic "stage." IN HOLOGRAM: An image of the starship hangs in space. Glo text reads "Look through the eyes of the Starship Excelsi Jim goes to the control podium. Touches the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a voice as deep as God's) What can I show you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're supposed to land pretty soon, but it looks like I'm the only one awake. Is that normal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. What can I show you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show me Homestead II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN HOLOGRAM: The planet Homestead II, Earth's twin sister

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Homestead II is the fourth planet in the Bhakti system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. And how soon are we landing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approximately ninety years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We land on Homestead II in ninety years, three weeks, and one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. How long ago did we leave Earth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Approximately thirty years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim stares at the hologram in horrified realization.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I woke up too soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I.  HIBERNATION BAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim sprints down a row of hibernation pods. Heart poundin Slides to a stop in front of his empty pod. Jim fusses with the controls, pressing buttons. But the screen just reads "PASSENGER DISCHARGED." Crouching, he pulls at the pod's canopy, trying to open i with his hands. It doesn't budge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to be in there!

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Jim trudges between rows of sleeping passengers to the af end of the huge Hibernation Bay. There he finds a hatch labeled CREW HIBERNATION FACILITY. Jim opens it eagerly - and finds another armored hatch wi small porthole. Labels reads FIREWALL and SECURE ACCESS A Jim presses the switch. No result. He peers through the porthole. Inside, the entire crew of starship stands sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim stands at another Infomat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do I make a phone call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your cabin telephone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Long distance. How do I send a message to Earth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interstellar messages are sent by laser array. Speak to the Duty Officer in the Comm Center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ONSCREEN: The Infomat displays a helpful map.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please note that interstellar messaging is an expensive service.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bite me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy to help!

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Two communications booths for passenger use. Jim sits at of these. Swipes his shipcard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Planet and connection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earth. The HomeStead Company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are thirty thousand phone numbers listed under "HomeStead Company." What number?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm emigrating to Homestead II. I have an emergency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Division of Colonial Affairs, Homestead II Program. I have a Customer Help Line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds about right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The booth's camera zooms in on Jim's face. A microphone extends toward his mouth. The red RECORDING light comes o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begin message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's a deer in the headlights. He collects himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. I'm Jim Preston. I'm a passenger on the Excelsior. Something went wrong with my hibernation pod and I woke up too soon. Ninety years too soon. I can't get back to sleep. Nobody else is awake. (with growing panic) If I don't figure something out, I'm going to die of old age before we get to Homestead II. So help me out here. (takes a deep breath) I'll keep trying to fix this. Maybe I missed something simple. But I could use a hand. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim pushes the "SEND" button. Sits back in his chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Message sent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outstanding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Message will arrive in nineteen years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earliest possible reply in fifty-five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are nineteen light years from Earth. By the time your message arrives, we will be thirty-six light- years from Earth. We apologize for the delay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-five years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That will be six thousand dollars.  GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim crosses the Concourse like a sleepwalker in his robe slippers. He looks shell-shocked. He comes to the Concourse Bar: the fanciest watering hole the ship. Black leather stools along a marble bartop. Jim touches the bartop...and a MAN swings up behind the b as if mounted on a hinge. A handsome fellow in a bartende uniform - his hair and skin eerily perfect. This is ARTHU Jim jumps out of his skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I was the only one awake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it. It's the middle of the afternoon. Are you drinking or not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He produces a cloth and polishes the bartop. In a startli movement, he glides the length of the bar, polishing all way, and glides back as if on roller skates. Jim steps up on the footrail and peers behind the bar. Arthur's body stops at the waist. He's mounted on rails, built into the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a robot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Android, technically. Arthur's the name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (taking a seat) I'm Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur shakes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pleased to meet you. What'll it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whiskey, neat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur pours. Jim knocks the drink back. Points into the empty glass while his eyes water. Arthur pours another. J takes a big swallow and sets the glass down half-full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, how much do you know about the ship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I know some things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I do if my hibernation pod malfunctions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Impossible. Hibernation pods are fail- safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, I woke up early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't happen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long until we get to Homestead II?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ninety years or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when are all of us passengers supposed to wake up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until the last two months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how can I be sitting here with ninety years to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur's eyes take on a faraway look. His head twitches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not possible for you to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He smiles as if he's solved the problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Jim. My specialty is cocktails and conversation. Take your fancy trick questions to one of those Infomats. They think they know everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, I'm in trouble. I'm screwed. I am completely, ridiculously screwed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lot of self-pity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Self pity? I'm going to die of old age on this ship!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, we all die. Even androids end up on the scrap heap. It's not dying that matters, it's living. This is your life. Are you going to live it or lie down and die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim shakes his head in surrender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do I owe you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, the booze is on the house.

dialogues.speaker: DECK NINE
dialogues.text: A moody lounge with panoramic windows. Jim walks in. Stro up to the glass. Stares out at the red stars behind the ship, the cold whi stars all around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim wakes up and rolls out of bed. Shuffles into the show  CAFETERIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Machines offer food and drink in dizzying variety. Each machine has a card slot and a screen displaying its menu. Jim enters, dressed in his own clothes - jeans, a T-shirt

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He swipes his shipcard at a coffee machine. It offers six kinds of coffee, from a simple cup of joe to the "Mocha Cappuccino Extreme." Jim picks the best of the lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry. The Mocha Cappuccino Extreme is reserved for gold-class passengers. Please select another item.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim presses one button after another, denied each time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry...sorry...sorry...Large coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please enjoy.  ELEVATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim ascends, sipping coffee and eating an egg sandwich. The doors open at the Command Deck. A sign reads "Crew Ar No Passengers beyond this point." Jim breezes past the si  COMMAND DECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim prowls the floor, opening doors. He finds a room marked EMERGENCY GEAR and opens it eagerl It's full of space suits and oxygen tanks. He peers into a red HAZARD cabinet: fire extinguishers, a axe, an epoxy foamer for atmosphere leaks - all behind gl He opens another door marked EMERGENCY MANUALS - and smil shelf after shelf of waterproof, fireproof technical manu Jim pulls a manual labeled HIBERNATION SYSTEMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cavernous cargo hold. Jim drives a forklift down the ai scanning container numbers. He finds a container labeled "PASSENGER #1498, JAMES PRESTON." The forklift pulls it from the rack.

dialogues.speaker: THE CARGO CONTAINER
dialogues.text: Opens to reveal Jim's belongings. Cartons marked "sports" "clothes" or "kitchen stuff." Amidst the cartons, a heavy-duty TOOLBOX. Jim hauls it ou  HIBERNATION BAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim sits in front of his empty hibernation pod. His toolb beside him. The Hibernation Systems manual lies open. Jim tinkers with the electronics inside his pod. The pod hums to life. Its data screen flickers with information. Mysterious WHIRS and THUNKS. The canopy opens. Elated, Jim bounces to his feet. Strips off his shirt and scrambles in. The canopy closes over him. He assumes the position, his back against the backrest, waiting for the pod to put him to sleep. Nothing happens. He pokes at the ports where the sensors intravenous lines used to protrude. Shakes the machine. He gives up. It's not working. But now he's trapped inside the pod. He pushes at the canopy, but it's locked shut. He pounds the glass with no effect. Finally he loses it, shouting a stamping, hammering and raging - all muffled behind glass Exhausted, he sinks to the floor of the pod, staring out his tools and his manual, his discarded shirt. Then he notices the emergency release handle down by the floor. He pulls it, and the canopy pops open.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE THE POD
dialogues.text: The pod's display screen blinks back to its original mess PASSENGER DISCHARGED.

dialogues.speaker: CREW HIBERNATION FACILITY DOOR
dialogues.text: Jim looks through the porthole at the sleeping crew. Jim swipes his shipcard through the door switch. ACCESS DENIED. He pokes at the keypad. ACCESS DENIED.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim opens his toolbox, selects a tool and starts to remov the keypad's cover plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim works on the door with an industrial LASER CUTTER. Sp fly. He's drenched in sweat. Mussed and unshaven. He lifts the goggles and inspects the door. The laser cut has barely marked the surface. The door's a mess. Its switch hangs on wires. There are p marks around the latch. Gouges around the window. Failed drill holes. Dents left by an axe. But the door stands firm. Jim lets the laser cutter fall. It joins a scrapyard of t on the floor: sledgehammer, jackhammer, drill, crowbar, a

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Another debris field surrounds Jim's hibernation pod. Too and cables, electronic instruments, a diagnostic laptop. Jim stalks by without so much as a sideways glance.

dialogues.speaker: CONCOURSE BAR
dialogues.text: Arthur stands behind the bar polishing glasses. Jim sits, sweaty and grimy, a whiskey in front of him. His speech is soft around the edges. He's had a few.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought I'd figure something out. I thought it would just come to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stands to reason.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I've tried everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes you can't catch a break.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim gives Arthur a thoughtful look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm your only customer, but you're always polishing a glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trick of the trade. Makes people nervous when a bartender just stands there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Lay some bartender wisdom on me. I'm lost in space here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur polishes the bar while he thinks that one over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not where you want to be. You feel like you're supposed to be somewhere else. Right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, here's the thing. Say you could snap your fingers and be wherever you wanted to be. Back on Earth, or on Homestead II.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet even if you got your wish, you'd still feel this way. Not in the right place. Supposed to be somewhere else. That's not a crisis, it's the human condition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim takes a moment to consider that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe not. The point is, you can't get so wrapped up in where you'd rather be that you forget to make the most of where you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you telling me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a big ship. You're always running around banging on things and yelling at the computers. Take a break. Live a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim spins on his barstool, surveying the Grand Concourse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Live a little.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When he comes back around he gives a shove. He spins fast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the spirit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim goes for one more shove. Misses. Falls off his stool.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim scans a map of the ship. Second-class cabins. First-c cabins. And the good stuff: palatial suites named for European cities. His finger stops on one of the biggest. The Berlin Suite.  BERLIN SUITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High ceilings, posh furniture, panoramic windows. The door jumps in its frame with a THUNK. Slides open. Ji enters, a crowbar in hand. A cargo robot follows him in, carrying his toolbox and suitcases. It deposits them on the floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Berlin Suite! Enjoy your luggage!

dialogues.speaker: BERLIN SUITE
dialogues.text: Jim cleans up in the opulent bathtub. A robot arm with a water jet washes his back.

dialogues.speaker: BERLIN SUITE
dialogues.text: Jim unpacks. Stowing clothes in closets, laying out memen He pulls a pair of sneakers out of his luggage.

dialogues.speaker: DECK TWO
dialogues.text: Jim shoots baskets in sneakers and gym clothes. He's not He shoots, rebounds, shoots.  SPA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim lies on a massage table wearing a towel. A pair of ro arms emerge from the table and begin to massage him.

dialogues.speaker: DECK THREE
dialogues.text: The Italian restaurant. Cafe tables, white tablecloths. Jim sits perusing a menu. A robotic waiter - a machine, n counterfeit human - rolls up to the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me have the rigatoni alla diabla, with the sauteed spinach and a glass of the Montepulciano.

dialogues.speaker: DECK TWO
dialogues.text: A state-of-the-art game room. Jim inspects the flagship g "Z Factor!" A huge holographic display, a futuristic cock Jim swipes his shipcard. The game speaks like an angry gi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim Preston! Welcome to the cutting edge of gaming! The greatest challenge you will ever know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clambers into the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you ready to play Z Factor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an echoing roar) Begin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IN HOLOGRAM: A fortress shines on a hilltop. War machines crawl over a blasted land. Letters flash: LEVEL ONE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A WARRIOR appears. Jim's character. Jim works the control IN HOLOGRAM: The Warrior rises off the ground on a beam o light - and is immediately torn to pieces by enemy fire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lose! Z Factor reigns supreme!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The game howls with demonic laughter.

dialogues.speaker: DECK FOUR
dialogues.text: A classic theater. Seats for a thousand. A velvet curtain Jim enters. Cued by his arrival, the curtain parts. The f begins. Jim settles into a seat.

dialogues.speaker: DECK TWO
dialogues.text: Jim is playing "Z Factor!" and he's on fire. IN HOLOGRAM: The Warrior battles dragons above a crystall city. A title announces "Level 40." Jim moves like a martial artist, dripping sweat. IN HOLOGRAM: The Warrior challenges the game's Final Enem a colossus with a hundred eyes. The Final Enemy falls dea

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are victorious!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the Grand Master of Z Factor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the Grand Master of Z Factor!

dialogues.speaker: GYMNASIUM
dialogues.text: Jim shoots baskets. He's brought dozens of balls onto the court. He no longer rebounds, just grabs the nearest ball He shoots from half court. From even farther away. Long shots, bounce shots off the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He launches a full-court shot, bangs it off the rim, and himself topple over backward. Lies staring at the ceiling

dialogues.speaker: BELLA CANTINA
dialogues.text: The ship's Mexican restaurant. It has the same robot wait as the Italian place, but here they wear sombreros. Jim sits over the wreckage of his lunch. He downs a marga and puts the empty glass down beside several others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another margarita!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have had many, senor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Margarita otra vez!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Si, senor.

dialogues.speaker: LIBRARY
dialogues.text: A room full of workstations, each with a reading machine. sits at one in a headset, taking a Russian Language cours

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Gudonov Russian Language Course. Level One. Let's begin. Repeat after me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [I am beginning to learn.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: [I am beginning to learn.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am beginning to learn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am beginning to learn.

dialogues.speaker: CONCOURSE BAR
dialogues.text: Jim sits drinking. Three glasses in front of him. Drunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in bad Russian, subtitled) [I be study the Russian.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in perfect Russian, subtitled) [Good for you! It's a beautiful language.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You speak Russian!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. We have Russian passengers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm trying new things. From now on, every time I sit down, I want a drink I haven't had before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fair enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur mixes a bright green drink, sets it in front of Ji Jim takes a sip and makes a horrible face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something new.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim sleeps in his luxurious bed. The covers knotted aroun him. He hasn't shaven in weeks. His eyes open. He lies staring at the ceiling. After a long moment he gets up. Shuffles toward the bathr in his underwear. He's put on a beer gut.

dialogues.speaker: CAFETERIA
dialogues.text: Jim walks past empty tables. Dials up a coffee and a roll Sits sipping coffee and staring at nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ARCADE ENTRANCE
dialogues.text: Flashes and blasts of noise. The sounds of Z Factor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are victorious!

dialogues.speaker: AT THE Z-FACTOR MACHINE
dialogues.text: Jim sits blank-faced in the cockpit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New high score!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bored, Jim punches his name into the High Scores board. J All the other high scores say JIM.

dialogues.speaker: CONCOURSE BAR
dialogues.text: Jim walks up to the bar and slides onto a stool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in fluent Russian, subtitled) [I'm ready for today's new drink]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Russian, subtitled) [I'm afraid I can't help you, my friend.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim thumps his fist on the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in Russian, subtitled) [Don't argue with me, robot. Give me a new drink.]

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no new drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can make two thousand, seven hundred and thirty-eight cocktails. You've had them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The news hits Jim like a death in the family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are no new drinks.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHTCLUB
dialogues.text: On the holographic stage, a sexy LOUNGE SINGER in a slink dress croons a torch song. Jim stands just inches away. He touches her face. The hologram dissolves into static.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim drops his hand, restoring the illusion. Closes his ey in an agony of loneliness.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim walks past the upscale shops, blind to their displays He comes to a PHOTO BOOTH. The promotional pictures on th side catch his attention: people clowning, smiling, kissi He pulls back the curtain, sits in the booth. The curtain falls. The strobe flashes. A photostrip drops into the tray outside the machine: fou identical shots of Jim staring into the lens without emot

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Jim walks numbly along, ignoring the stellar view. He mun potato chips out of a bag. A SWEEPER ROBOT follows him like a dog, collecting crumbs Jim feeds it chips. One for Jim, one for the robot.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Jim enters, still munching chips. The sweeper robot follo Jim stands at the windows. Stares out into the dark. Sigh terrible sigh. Suddenly he's wracked by sobs. Tears welling up. He leans forehead against the glass. Moaning. After a moment he sits down blindly. The whole room begins to slide past him. Confused, Jim looks around. He's accidentally sat down on sweeper robot: it carries him across the room.  TRAVELING SHOT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The robot carries Jim up and down the Celestial Promenade Down an elevator. Past the Concourse Bar. Jim waves. Arthur waves back, speechless.  DECK ONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The robot heads into a low hatch. Jim ducks to fit throug

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROBOTICS CENTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mechanical hive. Here the ship's robots are cleaned, repaired, recharged. Robots bustle everywhere - never colliding, never getting lost. A ballet. Jim's sweeper robot vomits its load of collected dirt int waste chute. Heads into a recharging niche. Jim jumps off. He explores: it's an engineer's fantasia. Jim's eyes show signs of life. But it's a hazardous place, with cranes an platforms, hoses and blowtorches on the move. He exits through another low hatch to find himself in the  HIBERNATION BAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands of sleepers in their glass tubes. Jim walks amo them, looking at their faces. Suddenly he stops, staring. Inside a pod, a woman stands sleeping. This is AURORA DUNN. A breathtaking beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? (peers at her data screen) Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves on, browsing people. Stops. Backtracks. He stand front of Aurora, looking in through the glass. He glances at her data screen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New York City. Journalist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A workstation. Jim types "Aurora Dunn" into a search engi It returns a list of New Yorker articles. Some titles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The New Corporate Overlords Patient or Patent? Genetic Medicine and You Modern Love: Dating the Database Jim moves the articles onto a digital slate.

dialogues.speaker: CONCOURSE BAR
dialogues.text: Jim sits reading one of Aurora's articles. Arthur keeps b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know ninety percent of the businesses in the world are owned by just eight companies?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's good. She knows her stuff, and she's not afraid of anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Aurora?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman. A passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim lies asleep, wearing boxer shorts and a full beard. T suite's a wreck. Laundry and dishes litter the floor. His eyes open. He looks at the stars outside. Gropes unde the pillow and pulls out a remote control. Punches a butt The window shades come down, hiding the view.  CORRIDOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim emerges from his room in boxer shorts and slippers. H dragging a blanket. A housekeeping robot, its dustpan quivering in anticipati hovers outside his door. Jim taps the "Do Not Disturb" button on his door panel an walks away. The housekeeping robot squeals in frustration as the door closes over the mess inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CAFETERIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim pours milk over a bowl of cereal.  ELEVATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim descends, the blanket draped over his shoulders like serape. He holds his bowl of cereal in both hands.

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Jim stands eating cereal and staring at Aurora. His eyes never stray from her face.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim glowers at the bar in his boxers and blanket. The cer bowl on the bar beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not saying the universe is evil. It's just got an ugly sense of humor. It doesn't just crush you. It crushes you ironically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things may look dark sometimes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You get to fly to another planet, but you die on the way. You're completely alone, with the perfect woman right in front of you, just out of reach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Aurora! Arthur, I'm falling for her. I've read all her stuff. Sometimes I talk to her and I know exactly what she'd say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Aurora's asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. (lays his head on the bar) I know.

dialogues.speaker: DECK NINE
dialogues.text: IN HOLOGRAM: Excelsior's progress diagram. The Excelsior hangs between Earth and Homestead II. A leg reads: "TIME TRAVELED: 30 YEARS. TIME REMAINING: 90 YEARS Jim stands watching. The numbers change with a digital click. TIME TRAVELED: 3 YEARS. TIME REMAINING: 89 YEARS.

dialogues.speaker: CONCOURSE BAR
dialogues.text: Jim walks up to the bar with the HIBERNATION SYSTEMS MANU Drops the book on the bar with a thud and takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. Say you were trapped on a desert island, and you had the power to wish somebody there with you. You wouldn't be alone anymore, but you'd be stranding another person on the island. Would you make the wish?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I've never been on an island.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. Say you figured out how to do something that would make your life a hundred times better. But it's wrong, and there's no taking it back. How wrong would it have to be to stop you? I mean, what if it made your life a thousand times better? How do you do the math?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim. These are not robot questions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim stares at Arthur in frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (spelling it out) I know how to wake up Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like a fine idea. You could use some company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be stranding her on this ship for the rest of her life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, you can't do that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim buries his face in his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim. I'm here for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, you're a machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim hauls the manual off the bartop and stalks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ship forges through space, its lit windows shining. Jim paces back and forth on a promenade, a tiny figure dwarfed by the mighty ship and the tapestry of stars.

dialogues.speaker: DECK TWO
dialogues.text: Jim passes under a sign reading "Hall of Faith," into a circular walk. There's a small fountain in the middle of the circle. Aro the edges, doors labeled: BUDDHISM, JUDAISM, HINDUISM, CHRISTIANITY, ISLAM, OTHER FAITHS. Jim walks the circle, looking through the doorways: a cro a Buddha, an abstract sculpture in the "Other Faiths" cha He continues around the circle and out into the ship.

dialogues.speaker: DECK FOUR
dialogues.text: Jim opens a door marked "Starboard E.V.A. Room - No Passengers Beyond This Point!" The E.V.A. Room is dominated by an airlock. Spacesuits in racks. Tools, tethers, shuttle docking rings. Jim goes to the airlock. Opens the inner door. A BUZZER sounds a warning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He steps into the airlock. The door closes behind him. Jim looks at the red lever that opens the outer door. He grips the lever. Looks thoughtfully out at the stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The airlock outer door opens with a blast of air. Jim eme from the airlock - wearing a SPACE SUIT. He plants his feet on the hull and walks up the side of t ship on magnetic boots.

dialogues.speaker: ATOP THE SHIP
dialogues.text: Jim walks forward across the giant skylight.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE BOW
dialogues.text: Jim stands, face uplifted. The cosmos reflected in his vi Raises his arms. Imploring the heavens for an answer. But no answer comes. His lifted arms fall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim stands looking at Aurora: a bearded pilgrim in a holy place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim stands at the sink with a futuristic shaver in his ha He talks to himself as he takes off his castaway's beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm shaving off my beard. (to his reflection) It's wrong, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whiskers pile up in the sink, wash down the drain. Hi face emerges from its mask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously wrong. You can't do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's finished. Clean-shaven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't even think about it. (astonished at himself) I'm shaving off my beard.  CORRIDOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim exits his cabin in his coveralls, carrying his toolbo He finds a squadron of housekeeping robots waiting outsid He taps the "PLEASE SERVICE" button beside his door. The robots zoom inside with squeals of joy.

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Jim stands in front of Aurora: toolbox in one hand, the technical manual in the other. He's breathing hard. He sets the toolbox down. Opens the manual. It's densely annotated in Jim's handwriting. He opens the pod's cover panel and goes to work, followin the steps in his manual. His hands shake. He starts to close a final contact. Stops. Gets to his feet. Stands looking at Aurora. Quickly he kneels and completes the circuit. Pulls his ha away as if the metal had burned him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora's pod hums. Medical data flows across its screen. vital signs re-start. Her pale skin flushes with color. Jim beats a retreat.  AURORA'S POD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora's perfect lips part. She takes a shallow breath - then a deep one. Her chest rises and falls. Her thighs shift as she bends her knees. The sensors on h body drop off and withdraw into the pod. She opens her eyes. They're beautiful. Her pod's backrest flexes, scooping up her knees as it becomes a seat. A video screen drops in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, Aurora!  BERLIN SUITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The luxury cabin now tidy and immaculate. Jim bursts in, wild-eyed. Drops his toolbox. Hides the ma up manual in the closet. He splashes water on his face. Stares into the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Aurora puts on her Homestead Company bathrobe and slipper Places her shipcard around her neck on its lanyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're ready to go to your cabin. Make yourself at home! Enjoy the rest of your flight, Aurora!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woozy, Aurora sees the other passengers still asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait! Why are all these people still hibernating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The screen pivots to face her. The Video Stewardess point

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora, your cabin is this way!

dialogues.speaker: DECK SEVEN
dialogues.text: Jim sticks his head out of his cabin, looks up and down t hall. Steps out warily.

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Jim approaches Aurora's pod, electrified. The pod is empt The screen reads PASSENGER DISCHARGED.

dialogues.speaker: DECK NINE
dialogues.text: Aurora finds her cabin. It's a first-class cabin, its doo overlooking the Grand Concourse atrium.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA'S CABIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Posher than Jim's original cabin. A king-sized bed, a panoramic window. A widescreen video screen lights up. The Homestead Compan theme music plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome to your cabin, Aurora! Your home until we...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora slaps the display off. Goes to the phone. A touch of her finger brings up the ship's telephone directory. Aurora selects "Information."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is available at that number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She touches other phone links, faster and faster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No one is available...No one is...No one...No one...No one is available at that number.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell's going on?

dialogues.speaker: DECK FOUR
dialogues.text: Aurora strides down the lane of quiet shops. Actively searching for other people.

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Jim paces nervously, glancing around. She could be anywhe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim rushes to the railing. Below on the Grand Concourse, Aurora is turning in circles, looking up at the balconies

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a husky whisper) Hi. (mustering a shout) Hello!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora spins. Spots him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I want to talk to you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll come down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim runs down six flights of stairs, his heart in his thr He reaches the Grand Concourse out of breath. He stops a paces away, just looking at Aurora, getting his wind back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passenger or crew?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passenger. Jim Preston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sticks out a hand. She shakes it firmly. Electric for First contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's lips move as she speaks her name, almost saying it her. Aurora. She doesn't pick up on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what's happening? Nobody else in my row woke up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I...same for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew's supposed to wake up a month before we do. But I haven't seen anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crew's still sleeping. They've got a special facility. I can see them in there but I can't get in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're saying nobody's awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But somebody's got to land the ship in a few weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's finding it unexpectedly hard to deliver the bad new

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have to show you something.  ELEVATOR A

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora ride upward. She looks out into the atrium watching the floors go by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Typical. There's so much incompetence in these big companies. No accountability! They lost my luggage on the flight to the spaceport. I'm leaving the planet and my bags almost didn't make it! And nobody apologizes. Nobody even feels bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim is only half listening - his eyes drawn to the spill her hair over her neck, the line of her jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the corporate mentality. (looking at Jim) Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim yanks his eyes away from her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Observatory.  OBSERVATORY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora's eyes, wide and staring. Her face a mask of horro In front of them hangs the starship's progress indicator the Excelsior hanging between Earth and Homestead II. Thi one years elapsed; Eighty-nine years to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a shocked whisper) Eighty-nine years to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other passengers aren't late waking up. We're early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora stares at Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've got to get back to sleep.  HIBERNATION BAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora walk down a row of hibernation pods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody strands me on a spaceship for a hundred years. I work for the New Yorker. I'll write an expose so hot you'll need oven mitts to read it. Trust me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not that simple. Putting somebody into hibernation takes special equipment. Remember the facility where they put us to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim points at a pod beside them. A middle-aged woman insi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This pod will keep her in hibernation as long as you want. And it can wake her up. But it can't put her back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think there's a way back into hibernation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not that I can see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There has to be. There's always a way. Where's the crew?

dialogues.speaker: CREW HIBERNATION FACILITY DOOR
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora stand staring at the door: scarred by Jim' many assaults. Aurora looks through the porthole at the crew inside. She runs her hands thoughtfully over the door's dents and gou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (dreading the answer) How long have you been awake, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year and three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora covers her mouth. Her eyes full of horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my God. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns her back. Suddenly she walks briskly away. And breaks into a run. Jim watches her go, astonished. After a moment he runs after her.  HIBERNATION BAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora runs down a row of hibernation pods, her eyes searching wildly among the glass tubes. She turns a corne Hesitates. Runs down another row. She's fighting tears. She puts on speed. Her sash unknots itself and her robe billows behind her.

dialogues.speaker: IN ANOTHER ROW
dialogues.text: Jim jogs along, worried. He's lost her. He pauses, listen In the distance, slippered feet. He runs that way. He stops: the sash of Aurora's robe lies on the deck. He picks it up. Runs on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns another corner and sees her. She's sitting down, back against a hibernation pod. Laughing at her own tears

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't even find the one I'm supposed to be in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim extends a hand. She lets him pull her to her feet. He gives her the sash, and she ties her robe around her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks back at her, miserable with guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't have told you like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. It just hit me how serious this is. How did you wake up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just did. I woke up, my pod dumped me out, and there I was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. We have to get help.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora stand in at a Passenger Communication Stat Jim swipes his card through the Comm Station's slot. It brings up his account information.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've sent...sixteen messages to Earth. A bunch to the Homestead company, one to the Space Administration, one to the United Nations. A couple to Homestead II, just for the hell of it. My phone bill's about eighty grand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How soon could we hear something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With speed-of-light lag, fifty-six years. That'll be from Earth. Nothing from Homestead II until we're almost there anyway. Eighty years or so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora's mouth goes dry. She swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the other planets?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other occupied worlds are even farther away. We'd die of old age before they could answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about other ships? (off Jim's stare) Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feeling very stupid) I never thought of other ships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, you've had more than a year! There has to be a flight plan or something...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They search the Comm Center and find a map table showing Excelsior's position relative to the Occupied Worlds. Aurora fiddles with the controls. Interstellar flight pla appear: a spiderweb of starship tracks between the worlds

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They inspect the threads of light - an icon on each threa representing a starship. Even Jim is excited now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we tell how far away they are?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The computer knows. Give me a ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (peering at the star map) The starship Zephyr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Round-trip message lag...ninety-nine years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The starship Andromeda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hundred thirty-two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Maximilian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eighty-one years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora deflate visibly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the closest one.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: The ship's lights turn the cool blue of evening. Jim and Aurora walk across the plaza.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know I should be working the problem right now, but I can barely keep my eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just came out of hibernation. It'll be a couple days before you're a hundred percent. You should rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I have to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll walk you to your cabin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim. Don't look so down. It's going to be okay. You've got me on the team now. Chin up, all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim nods, speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in cabin ninety forty-eight, if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim watches her walk away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in the Berlin Suite if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stops. Turns to look back at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year and a half? Must have been hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim sits down at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whiskey. Rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing. How's your day been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim takes a stiff drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora's awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Congratulations. (off Jim's face) You don't look happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur. Can you keep a secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a bartender.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't tell Aurora I woke her up. She thinks it was an accident. Let me tell her. Okay?

dialogues.speaker: AURORA'S CABIN
dialogues.text: Aurora sleeps, her hair a fan of gold on the pillow.

dialogues.speaker: BERLIN SUITE
dialogues.text: Jim lies awake, fidgeting and staring at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Aurora talks with a relentlessly cheerful Infomat. She's wearing her own clothes, and it's a transformation: looks hip and urban, beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can there be no way to put someone into hibernation aboard ship? What if a pod breaks down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No pod has malfunctioned in thousands of interstellar flights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibernation pods are fail-safe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim appears behind Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning. Have you eaten?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starving. This is the dumbest machine.  CAFETERIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim watches in astonishment as Aurora blithely orders the snacks that the machines deny him. The Mocha Cappuccino Extreme. The French Breakfast Puff. The Gourmet Fruit Sal They sit. Aurora eyes Jim's tray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a man of simple tastes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a silver class passenger. The French Breakfast Puff is above my pay grade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, no! All this time? What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm fine, really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. I'll be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up. In a minute she's back, setting a tray down front of Jim: A western omelette with a side of bacon...a cafe latte...half a honeydew melon. Jim shoves his old breakfast aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They dig in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think the crew members would know what to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we wake them up if we got in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no expert. But I think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe there's another way to go to sleep. Did you check out the infirmary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked around. It's the usual hospital stuff. Scanners, autodocs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you look for ways of going to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think they've got suspended animation pills sitting around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know until you look. What about cargo? Maybe there's a hibernation machine in the hold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked at the manifests. It's mostly farming stuff, industrial machines. We're not going to find a hibernation facility in a box.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know that! We have to think big here. Maybe we can build our own hibernation machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we can't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're not even trying!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been awake a year and a half. I've tried everything I can think of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (she gets up angrily) Well, it looks to me like you missed some possibilities. And I'm not ready to give up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She strides out. Jim watches her go. Reaches over and tak the Gourmet Fruit Salad off her tray.

dialogues.speaker: DECK TWO
dialogues.text: Aurora sits at a library workstation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No plans are available.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about research articles, any kind of technical documents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hibernation technology is proprietary. The following articles deal with the subject on a theoretical level.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora sits at the Passenger Communications Booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Planet and connection, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Earth. The New Yorker magazine, office of the Editor in Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begin message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Aurora Dunn. I'm doing a long-term piece on the colony worlds. I know you won't get this message for a long time...but you should know I'm in trouble.

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora inspects the gleaming medical equipment. Rummages through cabinets full of medicines and instruments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She opens a steel vault. A deep freeze: icy vapor rolls o Inside: racks of steel capsules at subzero temperatures. She leans close: each frosted capsule is labeled with a passenger's name and the word SPERM or OVA.

dialogues.speaker: CREW HIBERNATION FACILITY DOOR
dialogues.text: Aurora frowns through the window at the sleeping crew. A litter of tools still surrounds the battered door. Auro snatches up a crowbar and bashes the porthole. The bar sp from her stinging hands, but the window's not even marked

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Jim sits at a table with his tools, struggling with a hig tech mechanism. Aurora drops into a chair across from him. He looks up. T in her condition: weary and frustrated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no way we're going to build a hibernation machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's no magic sleeping drugs in the infirmary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did find the gene bank. Five thousand sperm and egg samples on ice. I should be glad they do that. By the time we get to Homestead II, that little capsule in the freezer is going to be all that's left of me. We really are screwed, aren't we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pretty much.

dialogues.speaker: BELLA CANTINA
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora sit across a Mexican dinner they've alread put a dent in. An electric candle burns between them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A robot in a sombrero drops off two mojitos and scoots aw

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who are you, Jim? I'm going to be seeing you around. I should know who I'm talking to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm from Denver. Lived there all my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of work do you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little of everything. Transport, robotics, industrial systems. I fix what's broken. On the emigration forms I'm a "rate two" mechanical engineer. Means I don't have a Ph.D.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither do I. But a journalist doesn't need one; she just needs a way with words and an attitude. I'm from Manhattan, so I had the attitude.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I noticed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the words have always been there when I needed them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would never have lasted a year with no one but robots to talk to. They're all such idiots!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not all of them.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim leads Aurora up to the Concourse Bar. It appears deserted. Aurora is all curiosity. Suddenly Arthur appears, doing his swinging-up-on-hinges trick. Aurora gives a squeal of surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening, Jim. Who's the lovely lady?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur, this is Aurora. Aurora, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora. A pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand formally.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur! Lovely to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She peeks over the bar at Arthur's mechanical mounting, t rails he rolls on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirty martini!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now this is a robot I can talk to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Android, technically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whiskey and soda.  LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Empty glasses show that Jim and Aurora have been doing yeoman's work at the bar. Both are tipsy and laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, I almost forgot my life is in ruins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That wipes the smile off Jim's face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for? It's time to sleep. In the morning we'll think of something brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Jim. Good night, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night. (to Jim, sotto voce) She's wonderful. Excellent choice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim drops his head into his hands.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA'S CABIN
dialogues.text: Aurora stows clothing in drawers and closets. She hangs snapshots on the wall: family and friends. Most the pictures were apparently taken at the same grand part She looks at them wistfully - and a look of astonishment crosses her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course!

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora pounds on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim! Wake up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens. Jim stands blinking in his bathrobe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go home!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls him down the hall, chattering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes too long to get to Homestead II. But we're still closer to Earth. We'll turn the ship around.  ELEVATOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora drags Jim in and punches the button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would take decades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's our only chance of getting off this ship in our lifetimes.  COMMAND DECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora drags Jim out of the elevator. Looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the...navigating place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That way. But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drags him toward the Bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can learn how to pilot the ship. We have all the time in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just one problem.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora opens the Bridge door - revealing the armored fire hatch just beyond it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything important - the reactor, the gravity drive - it's all behind firewalls. There's no way through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my last good idea.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora sits curled up in an armchair. Around her, a dizzy view of the cosmos. There's a cup of coffee on a table beside her. In her lap electronic slate with an attached microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: New file. My Voyage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clean page opens on the slate. The title in the corner: Voyage." As Aurora speaks, the page fills with words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I boarded the Excelsior on assignment. Maybe the most ambitious writing assignment ever given. But things have taken an unexpected turn. I'm not writing for The New Yorker anymore. I'm writing for me.

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora jogs in sneakers and sweats. Cabin doors flash pas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been awake on this ship for seven days, awake far too soon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead end. She's reached the aft end of the ship. She cros a lobby and runs back the other way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...and I might spend the rest of my life here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Running along a promenade, Aurora reaches the forward end the ship. Dead end again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...in a little steel world five hundred meters long.  GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim sits at a table, a technical manual open in front of He looks up. Watches Aurora jog around the atrium and van

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not alone. Another passenger shares my fate. A mechanic named Jim Preston.

dialogues.speaker: SWIMMING POOL
dialogues.text: The swimming pool is a marvel: one entire wall is a windo extending from the ceiling to the bottom of the pool. Aurora enters in her HomeStead Company bathrobe. Drops th robe to reveal a bathing suit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other passengers will sleep for another ninety years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She dives into the pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora swims, a slender shape moving on the water's surfa We pull out, the ship dwindling, the blue window receding

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the time they wake, Jim and I will have lived, grown old and died.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back on Aurora in her armchair, writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vanished, like a dream, in the blink of an eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
