dialogues.text: She falters, frightened by her own words.

dialogues.speaker: CAFETERIA
dialogues.text: Jim sits eating and tinkering with a small robot. The tab is strewn with dishes and tools. Aurora sits down across from him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim is thunderstruck. The game is up. He swallows hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emigrate. Leave Earth. I'm interviewing you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Interviewing you. You're the first victim of hibernation failure in the history of space travel. That makes you news.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you going to tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Posterity. So why'd you give up your life on Earth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim seems stunned by the question. He hadn't thought abou in quite those words.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hundred and twenty years' hibernation means you never see your family and friends again. You sleep your way to another planet and another century. The ultimate geographical suicide.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh...I never really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you running away from something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Things were okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted more, I guess. You know. More room. A fresh start. Back to basics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's HomeStead Company propaganda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a mechanic. A rate-two mechanic. We're a dying breed on Earth. But in the colonies, they still have problems to solve. My kind of problems. In the colonies, a handyman is somebody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing there for Aurora to scoff at. She looks impressed

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And there's room! Open country. Woods and fields. I like the outdoors. You know, room to grow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're back to advertising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't it still be true?  HIBERNATION BAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora walk down an aisle of hibernation pods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know how much the Homestead Company's made off its first planet, Homestead I? Over eight quadrillion dollars. That's eight million billions. Colony planets are the biggest business there is. Did you pay full price for your ticket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm in a desirable trade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So they fill your head with dreams, discount your ticket, and you fly off to populate their planet and pay HomeStead ten percent of everything you do for the rest of your life. You think you're free? You're just part of the business plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim waves at the rows of sleepers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you see here is five thousand suckers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see zeroes on the HomeStead Company's bottom line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see five thousand men and women changing their lives. For five thousand different reasons. You don't know these people.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim walks up to a hibernation pod. Glances at the data screen. He covers the screen with his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This guy. Banker, teacher, or gardener?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora studies the sleeper: a barrel-chested man of 50 wi gray temples and a jutting jaw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Banker.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gardener.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim moves down the row, peeks at another screen, covers i

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this Madison, Donna, or Lola?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora peers: a birdlike young woman with long red hair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's too silly to be a Donna. I think she's a Lola.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madison. Chef, accountant, or midwife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has to be a midwife. There's no way you made that one up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (chuckling, caught) She's a midwife. I didn't know they still had midwives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They move among the sleepers, quizzing each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at a man and woman side by side) Married, or strangers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Married.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating a young woman) Sixteen, twenty-six, or thirty-six?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd almost say sixteen...twenty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (about an older woman) Politician, historian, or artist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Artist?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't say. But I'll tell you this: I like her. We'd be friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at Aurora seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you can see that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at the woman in the pod. Smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora sit at opposite ends of a sofa - their fee almost but not quite touching. They sip cocktails.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was my plan. Travel to Homestead II. Live there for a year and see what emigrating's really like. Then back to Earth. I'm the only passenger on board with a round-trip ticket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I left Earth for a new life. But you end up back where you started.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I end up in the future. Two hundred and fifty years in the future. On Earth, which is still the center of civilization, overcrowded or not. And I arrive in the future with an amazing story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perspective no other writer has. Literary immortality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's this amazing story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The selling of the colonial dream.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Big plans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My friends threw me this huge farewell party. Everyone came. It was the happiest, saddest night. And look what it's all come to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, I can't think of anything else to try. To save us, I mean. I don't even want to think about it anymore. So. What is there to do around here?

dialogues.speaker: MOVIE THEATER
dialogues.text: Jim leads Aurora into the movie theater. The lights come The curtain opens. Aurora looks around in wonder. A bundle of cables snakes down the aisle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your step. I've made a few changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next to Jim's favorite seat there's a cluster of machines with power cables and hoses running to them. Jim and Aurora sit. A screen beside Jim lists movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got tired of running up to the projector room, so I moved the controls down here. Thirty thousand movies to choose from. I've only watched about five hundred of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He taps a button on another machine, which produces a buc of hot popcorn. He offers Aurora some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Popcorn?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora grins and takes some.

dialogues.speaker: GYMNASIUM
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora play one-on-one. She's not especially good but fiercely competitive. They jostle and scramble, laugh Aurora snags the ball. For a minute she just stands there beaming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you so happy about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm up two points!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She cuts around him toward the basket.

dialogues.speaker: DECK TWO
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora walk through the museum's white rooms. The walls display a Jackson Pollock collection. Aurora goes to the control podium. Scrolls through the me covers her eyes and chooses blind. The wall panels fill with Heironymous Bosch paintings - medieval visions of Hell. She winces and chooses again. A somber collection of portraits by Dutch masters. She frow Jim steps to her side and makes a selection. The walls fill with abstract landscapes - stark plains an oceans, with lonely figures isolated in the vastness. The images pull Jim and Aurora in: they stand before a da seascape. Without thinking she reaches out and tucks her hand in th crook of his elbow.

dialogues.speaker: SWIMMING POOL
dialogues.text: Aurora swims laps, cutting through the water. In the balcony above the pool, Jim stands watching her. Aurora, making a turn at the end of a lap, catches a glim of him but doesn't let on. Underwater she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: DECK THREE
dialogues.text: A cleaning robot scurries along the shopping street, look for spots to polish. Jim's hands reach into frame, pluck the robot off its whe

dialogues.speaker: DECK NINE
dialogues.text: Aurora stands at the railing, watching curiously as Jim crosses the Concourse below with the robot under his arm.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK C
dialogues.text: Jim stands at a workbench, the robot in front of him. He tinkers with its complex works.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim sits in an armchair with his industrial laptop. He ty a string of commands, hits EXECUTE. Beside him on the floor, his kidnapped cleaning robot doe figure-eight. Jim smiles in satisfaction.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora sits in her habitual writing position: cross-legge her favorite sofa, her writing slate in her lap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The starship's designers gave the ship a daily rhythm. The light is warm in the morning, bright during the day, cool at night. We need those changes. But I miss other rhythms. There are no holidays here. Every day is a day of leisure. There are no seasons. The sky never changes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A mechanical whir distracts her. She looks down. Jim's pet robot looks up at her with binocular eyes. It carries a note in a clip on its back. Aurora pulls it fre A handwritten invitation from Jim. It reads:  Come to dinner with me tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora reads the note with a grin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the robot) Is he asking me on a date?

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK C
dialogues.text: Jim sits at his laptop, watching the screen: a robot's-ey view of Aurora. He wiggles a joystick on his laptop, and...

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: ...the robot nods its goggle head. Aurora laughs. Beside the note-clip, the robot carries a pen in a makesh holder. Aurora takes the pen, scribbles on the paper. Tuc it back into the robot's note clip.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Arthur polishes glasses behind the bar. The robot crosses the Concourse, note clipped to its back Arthur watches it pass.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK C
dialogues.text: Jim plucks the note from the robot's back. Aurora's reply written in bold letters: Love to.

dialogues.speaker: AURORA'S CABIN
dialogues.text: Aurora gets ready for dinner. A slim gown, a few pieces o jewelry, her hair up. She looks like a goddess. The doorbell rings. She answers it. Jim stands on her doorstep in a black jacket, looking dap His eyes widen as he takes Aurora in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You clean up all right yourself. You went shopping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went shoplifting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the corridor stands a cargo robot to which Jim has attached an upholstered loveseat. He helps Aurora aboard takes a seat beside her. She's charmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rutherford! To the bar!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Passenger Jim!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The robot zooms off to the sound of Aurora's laughter.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora take seats. Arthur puts on his best manner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Evening. What can I get for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A manhattan, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Single malt, rocks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arthur pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You two look fine this evening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on a date!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Jim, teasing) Took you long enough to ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was giving you space!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Space is one thing I don't need more of. I've been doing research.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I found a drug that would put us in a coma indefinitely, and machines that would keep us alive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it's not suspended animation. We'd still be aging.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. If I have to grow old on this ship, I'd at least like to be awake for it. So that was a failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A highly ambitious failure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the title of my memoir. "A Highly Ambitious Failure," by Aurora Dunn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim laughs. He thinks for a minute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Voyage to Nowhere," by Jim Preston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My Life in a Tin Can."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "A Spaceship Built For Two."

dialogues.speaker: THE STARDOME
dialogues.text: A great glass dome, the highest point on the ship. Outsid the dome, a riot of stars. Inside, a luxury restaurant. Jim and Aurora emerge into the dome. She turns, looking at the glittering river of the Milky W the blue stars ahead of the ship, the pink stars behind t

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit at the best table. Robots attend to their every need. The blue stars frame Jim's head; the pink, Aurora's Beautiful dishes arrive: new wines with every course.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHTCLUB
dialogues.text: A holographic 12-piece band plays on stage: a jazz standa Jim walks onto the dance floor. Holds out his hand to Aur She comes to him, and they dance. They're pretty good. Sm grow on their faces. Jim spins her out, spins her back - close enough to kiss. They almost do - but they don't.

dialogues.speaker: DECK THREE
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora ride along on the cargo robot. Her head re on his shoulder. Suddenly she sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rutherford, stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The robot stops. She pulls Jim off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, we have to do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls him to the photo booth. They tumble inside. As strobe flashes, she kisses him hard. Outside, the photo strip drops into the tray: four color pictures. In the first they laugh; in the second they clo in the third, they kiss. In the last image, Aurora smiles the camera; Jim looks at Aurora. Aurora taps the pictures: they start to move: each is a o second movie clip. The pictures laugh, and clown, and kis

dialogues.speaker: DECK NINE
dialogues.text: The robot pulls up to Aurora's door. Jim helps her down. Aurora opens the door. Turns back to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I had an amazing time. A great night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too. Well, good night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns back. Aurora grabs him and drags him into her ca

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AURORA'S CABIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stagger across the room together. He backs her up against a wall, kisses his way down her throat. She drags his jacket off his shoulders. Pulls at his shir He slips the straps from her shoulders. Her dress slides the floor. They roll onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: CAFETERIA
dialogues.text: Breakfast. Jim watches Aurora eat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is so good. I'm starving. (she smiles at him) Last night was just what I needed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You are the most beautiful woman I've ever seen. You're so beautiful it hurts me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stares, shocked. Leans across the table and kisses hi Soon they're making out right on top of breakfast. A passing robot pauses to observe the scene - then moves

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: 1. Jim and Aurora make out fiercely in the movie theater while a movie plays onscreen. 2. Aurora straddles Jim in a jacuzzi in the ship's Spa. S moves against him: she's close. She climaxes gorgeously. 3. Jim stands on a promenade. Aurora passes, jogging. He gives her a smile as she goes by. A moment later she runs back into frame and tackles him. They tumble to the deck.  BERLIN SUITE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora lie in Jim's imperial bed, glistening with sweat and breathing hard. She lays her head on his should her eyes far away and wistful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm fine. It's just...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waves her hand in the air as if to signify, all of th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She snuggles in tighter, and he holds her close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the window, Jim and Aurora lie together in the luxurious bed. We pull out, the window dwindling, as the Excelsior soars away from us into the stars.

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: A luxury cabin door: the doorplate reads "Vienna Suite."

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA SUITE
dialogues.text: The best suite on the ship. One one side of the bedroom, Aurora's mementos and possessions. On the other side, Jim They wake together. She kisses him on the cheek with the of long habit and heads for the shower. He watches her go

dialogues.speaker: SWIMMING POOL
dialogues.text: Swimming, Aurora reaches the end of a lap. A hand reaches down and catches her before she can turn. Jim kneels at the edge of the pool, in coveralls and work boots, a tool belt slung over his shoulder. Aurora pulls herself up and kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to finish my survey of the cargo hold. See what there is to play with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back by happy hour.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora writes on her sofa, surrounded by electronic slate each displaying a reference book or research paper. On on map of the Polynesian archipelago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Polynesians set out into the Pacific Ocean with no destination. Searching for islands. They sailed into the endless sea on faith.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK A
dialogues.text: Jim walks among the towering cargo racks. His flashlight illuminates machines stacked from floor to ceiling: tract and combines, helicopters and seaplanes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some never returned, but others found land, and prospered. What drove them out onto the sea? Curiosity? Tradition? The wish for something better?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim opens cargo containers. He finds ingots of metal, computer components, spools of superconducting wire. Raw materials for a young world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The urge to move is as primal as hunger or thirst. We run, we drive, we sail, we fly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim finds a stash of utility golf carts and his eyes ligh up. He unpacks one, starts it up. Drives off into the dar

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Aurora sits at the bar with her slate, sipping a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it movement that we need? Or the possibility of something new?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing, Arthur. Hush.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora's slate has recorded this exchange: she erases the extra words with her fingertip.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK A
dialogues.text: Jim drives his cart into a new bay - and stares in wonder In oversized hibernation pods: cattle, horses, sheep, oxe All asleep. Chickens, ducks and geese in individual cells

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like seeds, we carry what we need. The wind drives us - whether the trade winds, the solar winds, or the winds of chance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The next aisle holds plants in stasis: saplings in tubes, seedlings in individual vials. Jim stops in front of a glass case. Rosy light bathes his face. He smiles. We don't see why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We take root where we fall. And helplessly we grow.

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA SUITE
dialogues.text: Aurora sits with her slate. Eyeing Jim's side of the room Giving in, she begins to explore Jim's possessions: pokin into the drawers of his nightstand and dresser. She opens his closet. Shifting things, she finds a dog-ea manual on hibernation pods. She pulls it out. There's a bookmark in the pages. She goes to open the boo and the bookmark slides into her hand. It's the photo strip Jim took during his isolation: Four identical shots of his face, bearded and hollow-eyed. The melancholy images hit her hard. She touches the pictures to make them move: but Jim sits immobile. In the fourth image, he sighs heavily. Voices in the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Passenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, robot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hastily Aurora replaces the manual. Closes the closet. Jim appears in the doorway: tool belt over his shoulder, duffel bag in hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I wrote a few pages. I'm not sure what I'm doing anymore. I was writing a book, and I was keeping a diary. But the book and the diary are running together. I think I'm writing about us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Makes sense to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I want to write about this life. I don't even know how to think about it. I live in a palace. But it's also a prison. I'm moving at half the speed of light and I can't go anywhere!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim takes that in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cargo hold is full of pioneer gear. There's a submarine down there, can you believe it? Ships and airplanes and bulldozers. That's what I wanted, a world still being built. But I'll never see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit for a moment in glum contemplation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you find anything that could help us?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I found these.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim unzips his duffel bag and takes out a bouquet of long stemmed roses. Aurora gasps. Reaches out to touch them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are they real?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I cut them myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora leaps into action. She finds scissors, a pitcher. the sink she trims the stems, arranges the flowers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks into his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For very unlucky people, we got pretty lucky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora sprint down the hall, cabin doors flashing Jim's practically dragging her along. A deep background RUMBLE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming! Run!  CELESTIAL PROMENADE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora run up the stairs onto the highest promena on the ship: glass all around, skylight above. The deep RUMBLE is louder. A bloody light fills the sky. A STAR looms ahead of the ship: a RED GIANT. The Excelsio rockets toward the star. The passage takes less than a minute. The Red Giant swell the windows. The ship shudders. The engines howl. Aurora falls into Jim's arms. The ship bathed in red light. The star fills the skylight, fills the sky itself. A fier surface turbulent with sunspots and mysterious currents. engines howl. And then they're past. The star recedes, dwindling as qui as it grew. The engines quiet. The ship's calm restored.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Closest we'll get to a star on the whole trip. Happy birthday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws her arms around him.

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA SUITE
dialogues.text: Aurora stands in her bathroom, getting pretty for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK C
dialogues.text: Jim puts the finishing touches on a beautiful RING woven gold and silver wire. It's crowned with a flower of gold. He removes the ring from its clamp: inspects it thoroughl Satisfied, he wraps it in a cloth and tucks it in his poc

dialogues.speaker: STARDOME
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora dine. They laugh and flirt with easy intim Their plates emptied, they sit back, sipping wine. Jim li the table's candle and waves it in the air. A robot rolls with a birthday cake, candles alight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Happy birthday to you... Happy birthday to you... Happy birthday, dear Aurora... Happy Birthday to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora sits bathed in candlelight, and for this moment sh truly and fundamentally happy. She blows the candles out.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora sit at the bar, tipsy. Arthur pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Birthday cocktail for the birthday girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you going to check my I.D.? I might not be old enough to drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd never ask your age in front of a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's not a gentleman. Anyway there's no secrets between me and Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Jim) Is that so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You heard the lady. Be right back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I like about you, Arthur? You have a sense of occasion. I bet ladies fall for you on every trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd say you were pulling my leg, but I haven't got any.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly! There you go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I remember your last birthday, a year ago. Jim was really looking forward to meeting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora frowns, processing this sentence - her smile fadin

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  MEN'S WASHROOM

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim stands at the mirror, straightening his lapels, touch up his hair. He unwraps the ring. Looks it over. Smiles at his reflect  CONCOURSE BAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora scowls at Arthur, trying to get her bearings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, he was looking forward to it? How could he...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He couldn't stop talking about you, let me tell you. He spent months deciding whether to wake you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora eyes widen in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim woke me up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, yes. Said it was the hardest decision of his life, but I see it worked out just fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora stops breathing. She stares at the bartop. Jim strolls up to the bar. His hand slides into the jacke pocket where the ring lies hidden. But Aurora's body language is all wrong. He stops, perple

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks up, her face rigid. Her voice a whisper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you wake me up, Jim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's hand slides out of his jacket pocket. He shoots a l at Arthur, who smiles back, oblivious. Aurora's eyes bore into him. Finally Jim finds his voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I woke you up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried not to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You pulled me out of hibernation. You destroyed the rest of my life. You murdered me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a little strong...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You murdered me. I'm going to be sick. Oh, my God. I...I can't see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He goes after her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get away from me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She slaps at him blindly, almost hysterical. Stumbles awa

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora stares out at the stars. Jim appears behind her. She speaks without turning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you decide? (turning on him) Did you just go shopping? A couple thousand women in their underwear, and you get to pick your favorite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wasn't like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was it like? And you had it all planned out! Dinner and movies and our big date...Oh, my God! And I just ate it up. Fake! All fake!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was real. I didn't plan this. It...happened.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Find true love on the Starship Excelsior! Romance between the Stars! The woman of your dreams!" Was it everything you thought it would be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora. I love you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is sick. (she glares at him) Show me how you did it.

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Aurora walks up to her old hibernation pod. Jim trails he

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim stares at her, unbelieving. But she means it. He open the cover panel, points out the key components.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I looked at my pod. A couple different processors burned out at the same time. I triggered the same failure in your pod. Short circuit across these two contacts, and then these two. And cut these wires.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so stupid. I fell for all of it. I fell for you. I thought you saved me. But you didn't save me, Jim. You did this to me. And now I'm stuck with you. Stuck with the second-rate mechanic who ruined my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rate two mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Aurora's already walking away.

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA SUITE
dialogues.text: Aurora walks in, barely under control, and breaks down. S to her knees, racked by sobs.

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Jim sits at the foot of Aurora's hibernation pod, staring into the empty tube.

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA SUITE
dialogues.text: Jim walks in. All of Aurora's things are gone. Her half o the bed has been made. She's moved out.

dialogues.speaker: DECK THREE
dialogues.text: Aurora sits finishing her breakfast. Jim enters and approaches her table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I talk to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to talk anymore. I don't want to look at you anymore. If you see me coming, get out of my way. If you see me sitting, find somewhere else to be. There's plenty of choices. It's a big boat.

dialogues.speaker: DECK FOUR
dialogues.text: Jim walks alone, hands in his pockets, in a deep funk. A little robot crosses his path: he KICKS it down the str  SWIMMING POOL

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora swims. Reaches the end of a lap and rests. She looks up abruptly as if she senses someone watching h but the balcony above the pool is deserted.

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora sits reading. Digital slates surround her. A whir distracts her. She looks down. Jim's pet robot sits beside her. A note on its back. She picks up the note. It's the photo strip from her firs date with Jim: their first kiss captured on film. Clipped the photo strip is a handwritten note: "This was real." Aurora leans down toward the robot's binocular eyes.  ROBOT'S POV

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora looms close. She holds the note up to the robot's and crumples it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching me through a robot is creepy, Jim. Cut it out.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK C
dialogues.text: Jim sits in front of his laptop: Aurora's accusing eyes s out of the screen. He closes the laptop.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Jim sits at the security console, disheveled and bearded. Twenty screens give different views of the ship. One screen shows the Elite Promenade. As he watches, Auro jogs by in sneakers and shorts. Jim has her route mapped: as she vanishes from one screen appears on the next. He follows her from screen to screen He picks up a microphone.  ELITE DECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora circles the atrium. OVER THE P.A. SYSTEM: Jim clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora stops in surprise, looking up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, just hear me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora rolls her eyes and resumes running.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Jim watches Aurora move from screen to screen. He holds t mic in both hands. His voice reverberates through the shi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The day I first saw you, my life changed. I couldn't forget your face. I kept coming back to see you. Trying to know you through the glass. I read every word you ever wrote, trying to hear you. The day you woke up...

dialogues.speaker: DECK NINE
dialogues.text: Aurora doesn't break stride. But she's listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you woke up I had no idea what would happen next. I had no reason to believe you would see anything in me. When you did, when we found each other, this ship I'm trapped inside suddenly felt like a limitless place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pointless life suddenly had meaning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora skids to a stop beside a Deck Steward's station. She leans over the counter, finds an intercom terminal an grabs the microphone. A whine of feedback. She looks into lens of the nearest security camera.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's great, Jim. Just great. I'm glad that ruining my life somehow improved yours. But I have a run to finish, so...

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Arthur looks up, listening, as voices echo through the sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. Aurora. Don't go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may be the only game in town, Jim, but that doesn't mean I have to play. Just pretend I'm not here. Because as far as you're concerned, I'm not.

dialogues.speaker: DECK NINE
dialogues.text: At the Deck Steward's station, Aurora stares into the cam

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to lose you.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Jim stares at Aurora on the video screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, you lost me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drops the microphone and walks out of frame. Jim slum over the console in defeat.

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Jim lies asleep on his bed in dirty clothes and shoes. He a shaggy beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Half-finished dishes in bed with him. The suite is squali

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: The ship's posh French cafe. Aurora eats a fancy lunch, reading a novel on a digital slate. She's groomed and put together.

dialogues.speaker: DECK THREE
dialogues.text: Jim sits in front of a bowl of breakfast cereal, a dry sl of toast. He stares into space. He has milk in his beard.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora sits in her writing chair, dictating to her slate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the modern way of life. We surround ourselves with people. A constant din of conversation. As if we need the mirror of other faces to see ourselves. The clamor of voices in our ears to reassure us that we exist. Do we need it? Can we live without it?

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA SUITE
dialogues.text: The TV blares. Jim lies asleep in an armchair, covered wi snack chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the secret to survival is productive activity.

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPING DISTRICT
dialogues.text: Aurora investigates the craft shop's shelves. Collects an electronic book on painting. Paints and canvasses. An eas

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need to be good for something.

dialogues.speaker: VIENNA SUITE
dialogues.text: Jim lounges in the bathtub in his bathrobe: sopping wet a drunk. Gold glitters in his hand: the RING he made for Aurora. He scowls at the ring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A challenge equal to our character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a snarl, Jim tosses the ring into his mouth. Chases with a slug of vodka straight from the bottle. Swallows h

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora stands in front of her easel on the promenade. She looks out the window and begins to paint.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something worth doing.

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPING DISTRICT
dialogues.text: Jim plays kick-the-can with the empty vodka bottle. Drunk The bottle clatters against the PHOTO BOOTH. Muttering in Russian, Jim attacks the booth, punching and kicking - and hurts his foot with a shout. He limps away. A moment later he's back - wearing his tool belt. He pull LASER CUTTER and starts carving the booth away from the w

dialogues.speaker: SHOPPING DISTRICT
dialogues.text: Jim drives his golf cart unsteadily across the deck. A HORRIBLE NOISE: he's dragging the photo booth across th floor by its power cord.

dialogues.speaker: STARBOARD E.V.A. ROOM
dialogues.text: Jim looks into the airlock through the small porthole in inner door. Red lights flash. The photo booth is crammed into the airlock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The airlock shoots open. The photo booth tumbles into spa

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Arthur does make-work behind the bar. Jim and Aurora approach simultaneously. They meet awkward they haven't spoken in a long time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You! Tuesday's my day with Arthur. You're trespassing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, today's Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I slept through Tuesday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it. The bar's all yours. But I'd say a drink is the last thing you need. You're pathetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora leaves. Jim takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'll it be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to kill myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a murderer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who'd you murder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she's alive. She was just here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She won't talk to me. She won't let me tell her what happened. How I fell in love with her. How I want to be with her. And I'm not sorry I woke her up. I'm not. I love her. And you know what? She loves me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Around the corner, out of sight, Aurora stands listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was I supposed to do? I couldn't live without her. It was now or never, and I chose now. I chose now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I was right. But I woke her up, Arthur. I woke her up, and she says I killed her. And now she's gone. She's gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme another bottle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you've had enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim looks at Arthur as if he's said something profound.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what? You're right. I've had enough.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK A
dialogues.text: Jim drives his cart up to a rack of large batteries: they identical to the battery that powers the golf cart itself Jim starts loading his cart with extra batteries.

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE DECK
dialogues.text: Paintings leans against the windows: Aurora's starscapes. first few are rudimentary, the later ones quite good. She works on a new one: a red nebula. She looks out the window - and her focus changes. She sees her own reflecti Her brush moves across the canvas. She adds the suggestio a cheekbone...a slender neck...an eye. A face made of sta

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK C
dialogues.text: Jim finishes connecting a bank of batteries to his cart's motor: quadrupling the power. He rolls a huge tractor tire up to the cart and bolts it

dialogues.speaker: DECK FOUR
dialogues.text: Aurora jogs. A rumble and wail of rubber behind her. Jim's monster gol cart comes ROARING toward her. Aurora leaps for safety as the cart passes. Jim blasts pa her with a war whoop and a wave. He wears welding goggles Aurora looks after Jim in astonishment.

dialogues.speaker: DECK FOUR
dialogues.text: Jim races down a long straightaway. Squeals around a corn Puts the cart on two wheels as he dodges a cleaning robot He steers down a stairway: The cart bounces crazily down the deck below. At the bottom Jim takes the corner too ha The cart tumbles and SLAMS into the bulkhead. Debris rain down. Jim lies crumpled in the wreckage, his goggles aske

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora sits in her writing chair, a slate in front of her But the slate is blank, and her face is tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't written in days. I don't know why. It's the old problem, I guess. Who's my reader? Who am I talking to? What's it for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to love it.

dialogues.speaker: SERVICE DECK
dialogues.text: Jim lies in the autodoc in his underwear - his head protruding, his body visible behind glass. Lasers and sensors pass over his body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two separated ribs. Fracture of the right arm, radius and ulna. One fractured finger. Dislocated thumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I gonna be okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blindingly fast, robot arms straighten Jim's elbow. Wrap ribs and arm with smooth white bandages. Jim shouts in sh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave the bandages on for one week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The autodoc opens and Jim climbs out, testing his arm. A bottle of pills rattles into a tray in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take one of these pills each day until they are gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, doc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And take better care of yourself.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora paints, wild-eyed and fragile. Her brushstrokes are fierce. She slashes at the canvas. A she paints she begins to cry, silently. She doesn't stop painting. The easel shakes as she works.  GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim kneels on the Grand Concourse. He's torn a huge hole the carpet to expose the deck plates beneath. With his laser cutter he cuts a large rectangular hole. P the plate up with a crowbar, opening a cavity in the deck  AURORA'S CABIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora paces in her bathrobe, hair wrapped in a towel. She looks at her gallery of snapshots. Touches the pictur one by one. The faces begin to move and speak. A cacophon good wishes. Laughter and cheers. Finally only one clip still plays. Aurora's mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise you we'll think of you every day. When you wake up, I know we'll be gone...but you just know that we lived our lives remembering you, and holding you in our hearts. (She starts to cry.) I don't understand, baby. I'm trying, but I can't believe I'm losing you. (She tries to soldier.) I hope you find what you're looking for. I hope it makes you happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora watches, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim, in work clothes and tool belt, drops by the bar. He' dirty as a coal miner but he looks happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Jim. Whiskey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Iced tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming up. Are you getting my barstool dirty?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got to get dirty to get things done, Arthur. If your hands are too clean, it means you're not making anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what are you making?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Improvements.

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora strolls listlessly. Glances over the railing at th Grand Concourse below - and gasps. She runs for the eleva  GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora walks wonderingly up to a GARDEN on the Concourse: ten-foot OAK TREE surrounded by flowerbeds and green gras

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Jim walks through Aurora's informal art gallery. She has abandoned starscapes in favor of self-portraiture The painted faces ever more tragic. The last one is a field of white. Aurora fading away.

dialogues.speaker: INFIRMARY
dialogues.text: Wisps of cold mist roll off the metal capsules. Aurora browses the rotating racks, reading names. With a start she comes across her own name. AURORA DUNN, FEMALE, BORN 4/27/2819.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She punches buttons. The racks rotate, shedding flakes of frost. She finds what she's looking for. JAMES PRESTON, M BORN 9/9/2810. She looks at the metal cartridge for a long moment. Then slaps a switch, and the genetic bank closes up on itself.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim sits reading an electronic slate. He looks up to find Aurora standing over him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last thing Jim expected to hear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I need a repairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim's face falls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim opens the door. Inside is chaos: the lights throb. St sizzles on video screens. Speakers blare noise. The blind jerk and flap. The adjustable bed convulses like a monste

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. You do need a repairman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark room. In the light of a utility lamp, Jim re-attac a control panel to the cabin wall. Aurora watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The control unit burned out. I took the one from the cabin next door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws a switch. The lights come on. Back to normal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora gives him a brittle smile and sits on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how are you doing? You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Jim. Thanks for your work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits immobile, frosty. After a moment Jim walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim passes a cleaning robot stuck in a corner. He frees t robot: it plows right back into the corner. Another robot zooms in - and gets stuck beside the first Jim studies the robots thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK C
dialogues.text: Jim tinkers with a malfunctioning robot. A squawk of static comes over the P.A. system. Jim looks up, listening.

dialogues.speaker: FORWARD OBSERVATION DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora sits with her digital slate in her lap. She too is looking up, listening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello! Anybody there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora bolts to her feet, wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK C
dialogues.text: Jim has vanished - the robot still rocking on the workben

dialogues.speaker: DECK ONE
dialogues.text: Jim sprints down the hallway, eyes searching left and rig

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Deck Chief Gus Mancuso.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim skids to a stop, astonished: the door to the Crew Hibernation Facility stands open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the hell planted a tree on my ship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Grand Concourse! Jim spins and runs back the other wa

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS MANCUSO stands at a deck steward's station, intercom in hand. A stocky man of 55, with a bristling mustache, wearing a crewman's coverall. Haggard and weary. He stare consternation at the garden in the middle of the Concours Running footsteps. Jim and Aurora race into the Concourse from opposite directions. They see Gus and stop, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing at the tree) Who did that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim raises a hand sheepishly. Gus shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't even talk about that now. Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim Preston. Rate-two mechanic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mechanic, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora. Aurora Dunn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus Mancuso, Senior Deck Chief. Nice to meet you. (looks at the tree again) How long have you been awake?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A year.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is not good.  CAFETERIA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim, Aurora, and Gus sit around a table. Gus leans heavil his elbows, sipping from a mug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I always get a hibernation hangover but this is the worst ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's just the two of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two years. Ouch. (looks them in the eye) You know what it means, right? There's no way back into hibernation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was hoping you'd know something we didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. We're awake for the duration. How far along are we? You know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-two years. Eighty-eight years to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus blows air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's tough. (he shakes his head) Hibernation failure! They said it couldn't happen. And now three on one trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora shoots Jim a look. Gus doesn't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, let's see what we can do.  COMMAND DECK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus leads Jim and Aurora to the Bridge's armored hatch. H swipes his crew card and the door opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no idea how long I've been trying to get in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you're in. Don't touch anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The computer consoles of the Bridge brighten as they ente Gus walks from station to station, studying the screens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're on course....Whatever's wrong with the ship, NavComp's still minding the store.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think is wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three pod failures? Something's wrong. Question is what.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He turns to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait. What about diverting the ship? Can we go back to Earth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus almost laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going forty percent of lightspeed away from Earth. To go home we'd have to come to a stop, accelerate back towards Earth, and then come to a stop again. It'd take as long as going on to Homestead II. Anyway, navigation's not for amateurs. Space is a big place, and a planet's just a little thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus has a coughing fit. Wipes his mouth with his fist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's go next door. See how the old girl's doing.  DIAGNOSTIC CENTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus opens a secure compartment beside the bridge. Inside, Diagnostic Computer stands dark and dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought we'd see a lot of red lights here. That would mean trouble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So everything's okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, if everything was okay we'd see a lot of green lights here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does no lights mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No lights means big trouble. Diagnostic Computer's down. We've got some work to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you need?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right now? Cheeseburger.

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: Gus eats a cheeseburger. Jim and Aurora sit across from h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with his mouth full) Never been so hungry. Worst hibernation hangover ever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim can't take his eyes off Gus. A new person.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So where you from, Gus?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Grew up in Chicago. But I've lived on this ship a long time. The Excelsior's made five inter-planetary runs, and I've been on every one. I live aboard. When she makes port, I live where she lands until she lifts again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doing the math) How old does that make you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how long ago were you born?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Hang on... (he does mental math) About six hundred years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Most of that I lost to hibernation or relativity. Doesn't really count. (he coughs again) I tell you, I feel about six hundred years old right now. I woke up hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should rest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I will. (he climbs to his feet) Tomorrow morning, eight bells, you meet me beside that tree of yours. Until I figure out what's wrong with the Excelsior, you work for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Gus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus waves and walks off. That leaves Jim and Aurora sitti awkwardly on the same side of a diner booth. After a moment Aurora moves over to the other side. Looks Jim across the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred years old!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora stares, caught off guard. She gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you in the morning.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Gus and Jim examine the Diagnostic Computer. Jim holds a flashlight while Gus pokes around with a voltmeter inside Behind them, Aurora stands watching with a digital slate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CPU's burned out, can you believe it? Why should that happen? It's rated for five hundred years.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you fix it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't fix it, you replace it. There are spares for everything in storage. Make a note. Diagnostic Computer CPU. And a new cooling fan, this one looks shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.  GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus and Aurora stand waiting as if for a bus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't take this the wrong way - I wish for your sake you were still asleep - but I'm glad you're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you, sweetheart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GROWL of gears. Jim drives up in his souped-up golf car

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The golf cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus takes in the bank of batteries, the giant tractor whe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This I like.

dialogues.speaker: SUBDECK A
dialogues.text: Jim pilots the cart through the stacks. Aurora rides shot Gus, in the back seat, plays a flashlight over the stacks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next bay is the ship's stores. So how fast can she go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim puts the pedal down. The cart lays rubber on the deck plates and shoots down the aisle while Aurora and Gus yel  SHIP'S STORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Up on a hydraulic lift, Gus digs components out of storag Hands them to Aurora, who hands them to Jim, who loads th into the cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIAGNOSTIC CENTER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus works on the Diagnostic Computer while Jim looks on. Nearby, Aurora thumbs through Gus's technical manuals. Gus clamps a final component in place and nods at Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Start `er up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim closes a circuit breaker and powers up the computer. deep electrical HUM as the machine boots up. The screen flashes a message: RUNNING VESSEL DIAGNOSTIC. progress bar shows that the diagnostic is 0.0% complete. The lights on the indicator panel remain dark. The first light begins to flicker as the diagnostic runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long will it take?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Full diagnostic from a cold start? Days. But it'll tell us everything.  GRAND CONCOURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus strolls through the ship, looking around nostalgicall He passes Jim's garden and shakes his head.  CONCOURSE BAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus walks up to the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chief Mancuso! Good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to see you too, Arthur.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I get you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just an ice water with a little lemon. I feel hot as hell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus mops sweat from his brow and sips his water. His hand trembles hard enough to rattle the ice cubes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GUS'S CABIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A homey space, filled with Gus's possessions: pictures of fellow spacers and vacation spots on half a dozen planets Books, keepsakes and mementos. Gus sits on his bed, on a handmade quilt. Coughs violentl into a handkerchief, leaving the cloth spotted with blood

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Aurora stands waiting by the oak tree. Jim arrives with t cups of coffee, and hands her one. Aurora smiles, touched

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus arrives in a fresh coverall, a steaming mug in hand. signs of frailty. He hands each of them a digital slate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right. Last night I checked ten atmosphere stations and two of them were burned out. Twenty percent failure rate. Unheard of. So we're going to see how far the rot runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. You're going to walk Decks Two, Three, and Four, and check every atmosphere station. Green light good, red light bad, no light really bad. Write down what you find, I want a complete census.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You. Go down to the Ship's Stores. Find atmosphere station CPUs and take an inventory of the spares. I know what the manifest says, but lists ain't facts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going down to the Hibernation Bay to look at our pods. Maybe I can spot what went wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora exchange glances.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That should be interesting.

dialogues.speaker: HIBERNATION BAY
dialogues.text: Gus kneels in front of the pod, examining the mechanism. Alone, he doesn't hide his difficulty: sweating and panti Something he finds inside the machine makes him forget hi symptoms. He stares, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Son of a gun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A sound behind him. Gus turns to find Jim watching. He lo from Jim to the pod mechanism and back again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're supposed to be doing inventory.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (holding Jim's eyes) I looked at your pod. Very simple. The clock chips burned out. Not supposed to happen, but it's simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim fidgets. Starts to speak. Gus cuts him off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pod was complicated. A bunch of different failures at once, the whole thing went haywire. I think that's why I feel so bad. (points at Aurora's pod) But this pod...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking what a lucky son of a bitch you were, stuck with a beauty like Aurora. But it wasn't luck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus sits down heavily, looking at Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus thinks that over, shaking his head at the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I could see there was some trouble between you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus starts putting his tools away. Jim lays the electroni slate down beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's your inventory. I'll be in the machine shop if you need me.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Gus sits working. Behind him the Diagnostic Computer disp its progress bar: the diagnostic is 9% complete. Aurora enters with a digital slate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finished the census.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You saw the hibernation pods?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you know. What Jim did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora's chin begins to tremble.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, he told me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He told you? Just like that? And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits, trembling with righteous indignation. Gus does want to get into this: he looks away uncomfortably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not forgivable, Gus. It's not. Don't tell me it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's a bad thing. But... (he shrugs helplessly) Look. When a drowning man drags somebody down with him, you don't call it right. But he's drowning. A starving man steals a loaf of bread, what can you say? You should have starved?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have starved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora looks hard at Gus, thinking, and says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ELITE DECK
dialogues.text: A rustic restaurant. Gus, Jim, and Aurora sit around a ta Gus reads an electronic slate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By Aurora's count, about thirty percent of the atmosphere station CPUs are burned out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can replace them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We will. But they'll just burn out again if we don't figure out why it's happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where do we start?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wait for the diagnostic report. You've been knocking around this ship for two years. A few days more won't kill you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus hacks and coughs. For a moment his weakness is plain see...but robots sweep in and lay dishes on the table. Gu sets his slate aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you go. This is the best food on the ship.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim, Aurora, and Gus sit at the bar. Arthur stands by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how did you end up in space?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only place I ever wanted to be. When I was sixteen I lied about my age and got onto a lunar shuttle crew. A few years later I moved on to planetary ships. Made the Venus run a hundred times, then Jupiter and Saturn. Then the gravity drive came along. Real spaceflight. I did everything I could to get onto an interstellar ship. I was thirty-six years old the first time I saw an alien sun. No going back after that. I've walked on seventeen planets in five solar systems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's incredible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you feel homeless?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a spacer. My home is where I am. You can't take much with you, so you don't get hung up on things. You have yourself. The things you do. The company you keep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus pushes himself off his stool. Momentarily shaky, he p himself together. He takes a seat at the grand piano and plays - a fine beerhall pianist. Gus touches a switch and lifts his hand the piano keeps playing. Gus stands and extends a hand to Aurora. She takes it, an Gus sweeps her across the floor. Jim watches from the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside, to Jim) Gus always dances with the ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora follows Gus's lead - but steals looks at Jim. Her unreadable. They watch each other as the dance goes on.

dialogues.speaker: GRAND CONCOURSE
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora wait beside the garden. They've been waiti for a while. Both look around for Gus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't seen him at all?

dialogues.speaker: GUS'S CABIN DOOR
dialogues.text: A doorbell chimes. Jim and Aurora wait in the hall, listening. Jim rings again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he's up.  GUS'S CABIN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus lies feverish and semi-conscious in his bed. A THUNK! The door slides open. Jim and Aurora rush in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus! Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, I'm not.  INFIRMARY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus lies in a medical scanner. Jim and Aurora watch as th machine bathes Gus in light, sensors floating over his bo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Couldn't get up. Weak as a baby. What does it say is wrong with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The scanner's display screen lists not one diagnosis, but hundreds: disorders, diseases, dysfunctions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hiding his horror) It's a few things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Diagnosis complete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus hauls himself out of the scanner. Pulls a bathrobe on comes around to look at the screen. He sees it and blanch

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six hundred twelve disorders found.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the summary?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pan-systemic necrosis. Progressive organ failure. Cause unknown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (losing his temper) I'll tell you the cause. My goofy hibernation pod is the cause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the treatment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No treatment known.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus pivots the monitor so that only he can see it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prognosis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A series of images flickers over the screen, casting shad on his face. Gus swallows hard and looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have I got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Between two and three days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long moment of silence. Gus turns and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These sedatives will alleviate suffering in the final hours...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pill bottles clatter into a metal bin. Aurora scoops them Jim goes after Gus.  CORRIDOR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus settles himself behind the wheel of Jim's cart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Jim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus puts his foot down and the cart squeals away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora stumbles into the hall, her hands full of pill bottles. She and Jim watch the cart recede.

dialogues.speaker: COMMAND DECK
dialogues.text: Aurora sits at the security console, watching the monitor Jim enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's not in his room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora flips on the intercom, speaks into the mic. Her vo resonates through the ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you? Gus, please answer. We'll be at the Concourse Bar every hour. I'm really worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is he? What's he doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They spin. Gus stands in the doorway behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guy's got a couple of days to live and he can't get any peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where have you been?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making arrangements. You kids have dinner plans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Xanadu at eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now stop shouting at me.

dialogues.speaker: GUS'S CABIN
dialogues.text: Gus makes a tour of the room, touching his photographs an mementos in farewell. He puts on his dress uniform: chest crowded with medals a decorations for the planets he's seen, the voyages he's m

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a photograph from a dresser: a handsome woman in forties. Kisses the snapshot. Tucks it in his breast pock In the mirror he studies his haggard face. Suddenly he SHOUTS, a wordless cry of anger. Pounds on th dresser with his fists. Teeth clenched in pain and fury. Then he straightens. Stands at attention. Takes a deep breath. Pivots on his heel and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: STARDOME
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora enter the Stardome to find Gus sitting sha but proud at the head of a table. They sit. Gus pours wine with a trembling hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look magnificent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ladies love the dress blues. (to both of them) Thanks for coming. Sorry to run out today, but I didn't have a lot of time, and there was a lot to do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sips his wine. Jim and Aurora watch with concern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How you feeling?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus, just because some stupid machine says there's no cure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: State-of-the-art machine, Aurora. Anyway, I can feel it happening.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you just got here. It's barely been a week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No point counting the days.

dialogues.speaker: XANADU
dialogues.text: Their dinners are nearly done. Gus pours more wine. He's the middle of a tale of adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pure oxygen environment is about as dangerous a place as you can be. A steel pipe will burn in pure O2. And there I am with a hammer, trying to close this valve and stop the oxygen flow, when one spark will kill us all. But the thing is, O2 makes you punchy. So I can't stop laughing. And then the guys behind me start in, and soon everybody's going. Captain's giggling like a girl. The Navigator pissed his pants laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim and Aurora laugh. But pain contorts Gus's face. He gr the table with white knuckles. And nobody's laughing anym

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is happening fast. I got some things for you. Come with me.

dialogues.speaker: DECK FOUR
dialogues.text: On a table at the edge of the plaza, a small pile of obje waits. Gus stops beside them. Turns to Jim and Aurora.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I went through the ship's manuals and made notes wherever there was something special you should know. These should keep you straight. In a few days the Diagnostic Computer will show you what needs fixing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes his shipcard from around his neck. Hands it to J

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This'll get you anywhere you need to go. Questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are we standing by the airlock?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God! Gus, no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got no choice about going. But I can decide how to go, and I'm going out on my own two feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure about this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you knew how this feels, Jimbo, you wouldn't ask me to stay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus extends a hand to Aurora. She throws her arms around

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus. I can't stand it. There's got to be some other way. Don't do this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus gently frees himself from her arms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, Aurora. It's all right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus turns to Jim. They clasp hands. Slap each other's shoulders in a rough embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jim. Fix the ship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And take care of each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gus turns and opens the airlock. He straightens, squares shoulders, and steps inside. Turns to face them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aurora covers her mouth. Jim raises a hand in stunned farewell. The airlock door closes. Red lights flash. Through the porthole they see Gus look out into space.
